LeadPara.Para: Top Middle East stories on Wednesday:

TailParas.Para: BAGHDAD: Embattled Iraqi Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari remained defiant after calls from a vice president for him to step down to break weeks of deadlock on the formation of a new government.
BAGHDAD: Former Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein dismissed evidence linking him to the mass killing of Shiite villagers as he launched a new tirade of abuse against his tumultuous trial.

JERUSALEM: Israel reacted sceptically to an unprecedented Middle East peace overture from Hamas foreign minister Mahmud al-Zahar to UN chief Kofi Annan, seeing no change in Hamas's refusal to recognise the Jewish state and accusing it of playing games.

JERUSALEM: Israel's Acting Prime Minister Ehud Olmert looked set to invite into his ruling coalition the ultra-nationalist Yisrael Beitenu party, which advocates the forced deportation of Arab Israelis.
GAZA CITY: Prime minister Ismail Haniya said that the Palestinian coffers were completely empty as he hosted the first regular cabinet meeting of his Hamas-led government.

PARIS: An Al-Qaeda-led coalition of rebel groups in Iraq posted a video on the Internet purporting to show the mutilated body of one of two pilots of a US helicopter it claimed to have downed southwest of Baghdad.
TEHRAN: The head of Iran's elite Revolutionary Guards said the United States must accept the Islamic Republic as a regional power which cannot be left isolated.
KUWAIT CITY: Kuwait has prequalified 11 international companies for the construction of a new 6.3-billion-dollar oil refinery with a capacity of more than 600,000 barrels per day.
SANAA: At least 25 people have been killed in Yemen in floods and lightning brought on by three days of torrential rains, the defense ministry's website said.
BEIRUT: The Beirut government was due to discuss a long-awaited reform programme ahead of an international donor conference to help Lebanon out of its economic and political crises.
